notes.title: FPSC CSS Geology — Official Syllabus & Past Papers
notes.content: Know the exact scope and weightings before studying. Post-2016 CSS uses the revised single-paper Geology syllabus; past papers (2000→present) show repeated emphasis on structural geology, petroleum systems, mineralogy/silicates, Pakistan stratigraphy (Salt Range/Indus Basin), geophysical methods, landslides and dams.
keyTakeaways: Use the official FPSC PDF to align topics and subheadings.
Mine past papers to spot recurring long questions and MCQs.
Plan diagrams for faults/folds, strat columns, facies, traps.

resources.title: FPSC — CSS Syllabus (Geology pages 82–85)
resources.description: Official scope for CE-2016 and onwards

notes.title: Structural Geology: Faults, Joints & Folds (with Pakistan examples)
notes.content: Master terminology (dip, strike, throw, heave), types (normal, reverse/thrust, strike-slip), joint vs. fracture, and fold geometry. Be ready to sketch and annotate map patterns and cross-sections; cite Chaman Fault as a regional strike-slip example.
keyTakeaways: Differentiate fractures vs. joints; faults show displacement.
Relate stress regimes to fault type (extensional vs compressional).
Use Chaman fault system for exam's Pakistan-context answers.

notes.title: Plate Tectonics & Wilson Cycle (Evidence + Pakistan)
notes.content: Connect plate boundaries, seafloor spreading, subduction and continent collision (India–Eurasia) to Himalayan orogeny and Pakistan's terranes. Use Wilson cycle to frame basin evolution questions.
keyTakeaways: Memorize boundary types and typical features.
Tie Indian Plate collision to Himalaya–Kohistan–Karakoram evolution.
Use cycle to explain opening/closing oceans and basin fill.

resources.title: An Introduction to Geology (Open Textbook) — Plate Tectonics
Kazmi & Jan — Geology and Tectonics of Pakistan (PDF)
USGS — Potwar Plateau & Salt Range tectonics (Bulletin 2126)

notes.title: Unconformities & Laws of Stratigraphy
notes.content: Identify angular, disconformity, and nonconformity in the field and on cross-sections. Apply Steno's principles and superposition; expect diagram-based questions.
keyTakeaways: Practice drawing and labeling unconformity types.
Use fossils and facies to support correlation across gaps.
Combine with structural attitudes for full marks.

notes.title: Pakistan Sedimentary Basins & Petroleum Geology
notes.content: Know basin names, tectono-stratigraphic frameworks, petroleum system elements and play types in Indus Basin (including Kohat–Potwar, Sulaiman, Kirthar, Offshore Indus).
keyTakeaways: Source–reservoir–seal–trap sequencing in time and space.
Recall classic reservoirs (e.g., Goru, Pab) and seals.
Use official basin maps in answers.

notes.title: Hydrocarbon Traps & Plays
notes.content: Differentiate structural, stratigraphic, combination and fluidic traps; sketch anticline/fault/stratigraphic pinch-out traps; tie to sequence stratigraphy.
keyTakeaways: Levorsen's scheme: structural, stratigraphic, combination.
Trap size depends on geometry, dip, and seal continuity.
Relate plays to Pakistan basins for context.

notes.title: Wireline Logging & Log Interpretation (Exam-level Basics)
notes.content: Understand what logs measure (resistivity, density-neutron, sonic, gamma), how data are acquired, and how to infer lithology/porosity/fluid type.
keyTakeaways: Define wireline vs. MWD/LWD; list common logs.
Use GR + resistivity + density-neutron cross-plots for quick lithology/fluid calls.
Know what a caliper or CBL indicates for well integrity.

resources.title: SLB Oilfield Review — Intro to Wireline Logging

notes.title: Geophysical Methods: Gravity, Resistivity & Seismic (Intro)
notes.content: Be able to state principles, field layouts and typical targets for gravity, DC resistivity and basic seismic. Sketch a Bouguer anomaly, Wenner/Schlumberger arrays, and seismic refraction/reflection concepts.
keyTakeaways: Gravity contrasts → density variations; exploration & basement mapping.
Resistivity contrasts → lithology, fluids, aquifers/contamination.
Seismic images structure/stratigraphy; selection depends on objective/cost.

notes.title: Silicate Minerals & Mineral Groups (Neso–Soro–Ino–Phyllo–Tecto)
notes.content: CSS repeatedly asks for silicate classification and key rock-forming minerals (feldspars, pyroxenes, amphiboles, olivine, micas, quartz).
keyTakeaways: Classify by SiO4 linkage; recall typical chemistries/structures.
Know plagioclase solid solution (albite–anorthite).
Link properties to hand-specimen identification.

resources.title: Open Textbook — Structure & Classification of Silicates

notes.title: Igneous Rocks — IUGS/QAPF & TAS (nomenclature)
notes.content: Be able to classify plutonic rocks with QAPF and volcanic rocks with TAS; relate to Bowen's reaction series and tectonic setting.
keyTakeaways: Use modal Q-A-P-F for phaneritic rocks; TAS for fine-grained/altered.
Remember alkaline vs tholeiitic trends and their settings.
Cite examples in Pakistan (e.g., Chagai magmatics).

notes.title: Metamorphic Facies & Barrovian Metamorphism
notes.content: Link P–T conditions to facies (greenschist→amphibolite→granulite; blueschist/epidote-blueschist in subduction). Understand index minerals and Barrovian zones.
keyTakeaways: Draw a facies diagram and place typical mineral assemblages.
Barrovian sequence: chlorite→biotite→garnet→staurolite→kyanite→sillimanite.
Relate facies to plate settings (collision vs subduction).

notes.title: Sedimentology: Weathering → Transport → Deposition
notes.content: Differentiate weathering, erosion and transport; describe clastic textures, carbonate textures (Dunham), and common sedimentary structures (cross-bedding, ripple marks, graded bedding, turbidites).
keyTakeaways: Relate grain size/rounding/sorting to energy and distance.
Know basic carbonate textures and allochems.
Use structures to infer flow directions and environments.

notes.title: Pakistan Stratigraphy Focus — Salt Range & Potwar
notes.content: High-yield locality spanning Precambrian evaporites to Siwalik molasse. Expect questions on successions, index fossils, coal horizons, thrust geometry and salt tectonics.
keyTakeaways: Memorize a simplified strat column with key formations.
Use USGS/BGS and recent papers for updated interpretations.
Tie to hydrocarbon systems (e.g., Cambrian–Eocene reservoirs).

resources.title: USGS Bulletin 2096 — Surghar & Salt Range coal fields
GSA Bulletin — Cambrian Geology of the Salt Range (open)
MDPI — Stratigraphic Controls in Salt Range (2021)

notes.title: Paleontology & Biostratigraphy (Forams, Trilobites & Index Fossils)
notes.content: Know what makes a good index fossil; use foraminifera in biostratigraphy and reservoir studies; cite trilobites for Paleozoic time slices.
keyTakeaways: Index fossils: wide distribution, rapid evolution, easy ID.
Forams are central to marine biostratigraphy and paleo-environments.
Tie fossil data to sequence stratigraphy surfaces.

notes.title: Engineering Geology of Dams & Tunnels (Site Investigation)
notes.content: CSS frequently tests dam site selection/investigation. Cover rock mass properties, discontinuities, permeability (Lugeon), seepage, slope stability, and instrumentation.
keyTakeaways: Integrate geology, geotech testing, and geophysics.
Recognize karst/soluble horizons and faulted ground as risks.
Sketch a dam site investigation workflow.

notes.title: Landslides (Northern Pakistan) — Causes & Mitigation
notes.content: Integrate lithology, structure, rainfall, seismicity and human factors; know monitoring and stabilization measures. Use Pakistan case studies (Hunza/Attabad, monsoon triggers).
keyTakeaways: Map susceptibility: bedding–slope angle, faults, saturation.
Mitigation: drainage, retaining structures, bio-engineering.
Cite NDMA guidance and recent InSAR studies.

notes.title: Groundwater & Aquifers (Darcy's Law; Resistivity in Hydrogeology)
notes.content: Differentiate confined vs unconfined aquifers, porosity vs permeability, and apply Darcy's Law. Know where resistivity profiling helps map aquifers and contamination.
keyTakeaways: Interpret cone of depression and well interference.
Relate lithology to resistivity (clay vs sand/gravel).
Cite standard manuals when writing procedures.

notes.title: Video Learning — Fast Visuals for Exam Diagrams
notes.content: Use concise videos/playlists to reinforce structures, seismic/earthquakes and mapping skills; reproduce diagrams after watching.
keyTakeaways: IRIS animations clarify seismic waves & faults.
MIT OCW lectures cover intro geology concepts.
GSP/Documentary videos give local context.
